Q: How to condense multiple boolean columns into one column in laravel? A:

while the other solutions provided here are more than OK, to answer your literal question "How to condense multiple boolean colummns into one column" the answer is bitmasks. You can make an enum from your badges, where each badge have a value as a power of 2 and store the sum of all the assigned badges for a user into 1 column.

Example:

$user->update(['badges' => Badge::badge1->value | Badge::badge3->value]);
$user->badges & Badge::badge1->value; // true
$user->badges & Badge::badge2->value; // false
$user->badges & Badge::badge3->value; // true

from this you can easily make a custom cast for your bitmask to get/set a list of enums instead of int values.

Q: #pragma omp parallel num_threads is not working A:

omp_get_num_threads() returns the total number of threads being used

omp_get_thread_num() returns the current thread ID

You should use the former one

Q: How to upgrade files with MSI installer that can have higher version of the assemblies A:

I've seen similar problems where Windows Installer incorrectly sniffs a version number out of a file that looks sufficiently like a PE file and refuses to replace the installed file with what it thinks is an older version.

We never did find a reliable way to stop it trying to be clever, so we moved all the files — other than the main executable where we controlled the versioning — into a unique-per-build subdirectory of the target dir (eg named as the full version number being built).

Q: python shelve - delete entire database A:

Since shelve creates multiple files apart from the filename I specify

No, it doesn't.

Here is the reprex you were asked for but chose not to supply. It is taken straight from the docs.

import shelve

with shelve.open('spam') as db:
    db['eggs'] = 'eggs'

Running this on MacOS under interpreter 3.14 produces a single file, spam, containing a Dict table that stores key, value pairs as binary BLOBs.

% file spam
spam: SQLite 3.x database, last written using SQLite version 3050004, writer version 2, read version 2, file counter 2, database pages 3, cookie 0x1, schema 4, UTF-8, version-valid-for 2

Simply unlink() (rm) the filename you supplied to .open().

Similar results may be obtained directly from python:

>>> import dbm
>>> dbm.whichdb('spam')
'dbm.sqlite3'
